though it may not be as powerful as its predecessor, it still packs a punch, and through the whole movie i was wondering what colonel mortimer would do at the end. regardless, it ended cleverly and did not disappoint.

Sergio Leone's "For a Few Dollars More" has a bit more to offer than "A Fistful of Dollars." It clearly isn't great in my opinion because it feels like Leone has not really found what actually works from start to finish.  There are rough edges, most notably in the climax where it just seems uneven, at times what the characters do and say works, at times the presentation seems disjointed. Also, the film tries to dig deeper, however it is unsure of what to do, relating to the past of Van Cleef and Volonte's character. Ennio Morricone's music is splendid! I particularly admired the sequence where Van Cleef and Eastwood are face to face. The performances are fine, could have been better, especially of Volonte, since he is the main villain. Then again, I think it really falls on the director's execution. The great Klaus Kinski definitely made his mark in the short screen time he had. Not much else to say but that it was still entertaining, I have great admiration for Westerns! A good picture, for sure.
Eastwood kicked a ton of ass in this film!
This was my favorite movie out of the man with no name trilogy

Even better than the first film in the series! With a more interesting plot and fantastic performances from Eastwood, Lee Van Cleef and Gian Maria Volonte this ranks right up there with the best westerns!
long live the spaghetti western!!!
I saw this again just last night. the whole thing seems huge; I'm surprized the narrative really holds together at all.

I think this is the first time that I've rated a Sergio Leone film lower than 5 stars, but I have my reasons. For a Few Dollars More, being the third in the "Dollars trilogy" (or the "Man with No Name" trilogy, if you buy into that marketing strategy), is not quite up to snuff with the other entries in the series - or even in the rest of Leone's body of work. First of all, there isn't a clear focus on who is who and what is what... that is we can't really connect with the characters because we have a difficult time latching onto their characters. It doesn't make for very compelling drama. Second of all, Eastwood's character seems to take a backseat in this one. He doesn't do a whole hell of a lot and is even a bystander in film's climactic shoot-out. That just doesn't sit well with me. The ideas are there, the score is great and Gian Maria Volonte's villainous role is just superbly performed, but it feels like a step back to me. I love Sergio Leone's work, but this feels weak, and that's saying a lot being that everything he ever directed is basically a masterpiece of the art form. I don't discount it, but it isn't the strongest entry in the trilogy.

Sergio Leone's For a Few Dollars More, the second movie to The Man With No Name trilogy, is yet another classic for the western genre and just as good as the first. For a Few Dollars More is about two bounty hunters, The Man with No Name and Col. Douglas Mortimer. These are two of the best shooters in the west and always catch who their hunting down. One day one of worst criminals, El Indio, gets broken out of prison which brings The Man with No Name and Mortimer together. These two killers team up to find this madman. The Man with No Name is in this for the money and Mortimer is here to seek revenge on Indio from what he did to him in the past. A Fistful of Dollars was a magnificent western and in the sequel For a Few Dollars more it doesn't disappoint what so ever, this movie is everything you would want for a sequel. The thing about this series is that each movie seems to get better and better unlike some movies were the movies just get worse. Just like the first movie this is a western classic. The story to this movie is just great because it was clever and fun to watch. There is never a dull moment in these movies and all the events in this movie are just perfect for the movie. Just like the first movie the shootouts are exciting and has some funny comedy. All the actors in this movie are great just like the first movie. Clint Eastwood is back and still the cool guy he was in the first movie but he's not the only cool guy in the movie. In this movie Lee Van Cleef joins the series and his performance in this movie is just amazing. His character is just like Eastwood's, clever, smart, and deadly. Every time Eastwood and Van Cleef are on screen together it's just great because they were a perfect duo in this movie. Overall For a Few Dollars More is another Western classic and if you liked the first you'll be sure to like this one.

Classic in its truest form. Leone manages in every shot, every scene, every little facial expression and every character quirk, albeit with a bit of editing difficulty for the released production, to portray the craft, the will, the greed and downright arrogance of man. He certainly had a heavenly gift (not unlike Kurosawa). And I cannot emphasise how much grandeur Morricone brings to his films. Sheer...fucking...geniuses...both of them!
Gets very close to "The Good, The Bad And The Ugly" quality.

Keeping the gorgeous stylization from the first installment was a solid choice, but now adding a far superior storyline, involving some pretty serious stakes, was an even better one. I like this film quite a bit more then the first. For one, I wasn't so distracted by the cooler then cool "Man With No Name." Leone refrained from the overwhelming amount of one liners and flashy gun tricks in order to bring more depth to the character, a very effective decision. I also appreciate the extended length of many of the scenes which was seriously lacking in the first. Leone never rushed through them, but instead took the necessary time to let us soak up every ounce of this boiling plot. Finally, bringing in Lee Van Cleef as Eastwood's counterpart was a brilliant addition. They have genuine chemistry together which only adds the the films greatness. This is the perfect film to follow up to an introduction like the first. I'm greatly excited to see how this fantastic series will conclude!
Another Leone classic
Western Spaghetti Classic....with a duel
Though not as essential as its predecessor, For A Few Dollars more shows Leone's style evolving. Nice addition with Lee Van Cleef as well.
This was another great western and a great sequal. For me though I always preferred the first and the third but I still loved the film.
i loooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooove this movie and i recommend it to everyone who would like to watch a movie.
OK but not great spaghetti western

better than original in many respects but just as awesome as original. the soundtrack is good and much of the music is repeated from original.
"Where life had no value, death, sometimes, had its price. That is why the bounty killers appeared."

For A Few Dollars More centers on The Man With No Name (Clint Eastwood) teaming up with a bounty hunter (Lee Van Cleef) in order to bring down a crazed desperado (Gian Maria Volonte). This sequel improves upon its predecessor by featuring a more emotionally resonant story that better showcases the strengths of the filmmakers. Eastwood and Van Cleef are at their gritty best while director Sergio Leone frames every scene with fiery and suspenseful intensity. It's almost needless to say that nobody can use music as a narrative device with the same flair as composer Ennio Morricone, but I'll state it just the same.
Sergio Leone's second western appears more folk legend than film.  Revenge, love, and greed set to Ennio Morricone's apparitional score make For a Few Dollars More Leone's best.
This movie is just as thrilling and grim as the previous entry in the Dollars trilogy but it does suffer from a few more lulls in the script where there hadn't been any before.
Good, but not great.
About as good as "Fistful of Dollars" but has a better villain and a better showdown at the end (that locket music is haunting, too).
Saying this isn't as good as the others is like saying Godfather wasn't as good as Godfather 2. The fun still roles, Eastwood's the man!

This is by far my favourite Western. The scene where El Indio gets out the pocketwatch for the first time is on my list of all time great scenes. The tension between the two protagonists is unbearable whilst Morricone's amazing score cranks it up even further. All the time the chimes of the pocketwatch play down to a fateful conclusion. Van Cleef out cools Eastwood in this one -'This train stops at Tucumacari'.
A significant step forward from A Fistful of Dollars, with the usual terrific compositions, Morricone score, and taciturn performances.

This is my most favourite Western ever, directed by the brilliant Sergio Leone. It stars the cool Man with No Name (Clint Eastwood), who in this is up against bounty hunter Col Douglas Mortimer (Lee Van Cleef), to capture dastardly bandit Indio (Gian Maria VolontÃ¨) dead or alive for a massive reward. Full of the best gun fights, shoot outs and stand offs, in a vibrant world full of gangs and twisted strangers. The film also has an incredible music score from Ennio Morricone. This is Clint Eastwood and Sergio Leone at their best.

A real step-up from A Fistful of Dollars, you can see how Leone had learned from the earlier film. There's less longeuers (though some, which is a shame), better pace, more warmth and more wit (which seems strange I know in a film with so many violent incidents). Really it's an excellent film that if it had fifteen minutes or so shaved off would have been perfect.

Certainly underrated, this film is grossly overshadowed by its successor The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly. Of the three films from the so-called Dollars Trilogy, this film is the deepest and most mature. From this reason alone it serves as a better film than The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, which is essentially just a popcorn movie with good photography.

The sequel to A Fist Full of Dollars nearly reaches the heights of the first film. It's arguably better, since it includes three deeply developed characters (and two American actors along with the impressive Gian Maria VolontÃ¨ as Indio) unlike the first movie (which really only had one character - the Man with No Name - along with a bunch of useful composites to drive the awesome plot). 

Lee Van Cleef was f-ing awesome. No other actor (aside from Eastwood and John Wayne) works better in a Western. 

There's one other area where this improves upon the original: the music. Ennicio Morricone gives us pounding soundtrack that's actually an important part of the plot. It's not quite as good as the score for the Good the Bad and the Ugly, but that one may have been the best ever produced.

One final note: the choices for Italian actors sometimes creates hilarious results. Indio's gang is full of some colorful weirdos. The english dubbing is a bit better, as well.
Not as epic as "A Fistful of Dollars," but thanks to Clint Eastwood's performance and pulse-pounding action, this movie is great, nonetheless.

I own this on DVD and on Blu-Ray in a three movie pack along with:

* The Good, The Bad And The Ugly (1966)

and i also own the "Two-disc collector's edition" DVD.
So good, so badass!! Lee Van Cleef steals the show. The last 25 minutes are outstanding!!
100% classic spaghetti western
Sergio Leone is in my top five of the greatest film directors of all time and this film helped keep the ball rolling.

The second of the Sergio Leone's famous dollars trilogy, and I frankly enjoyed it a lot more than a Fistful of dollars that has set the tone for better movies, including the good, the bad and the ugly that was released a year after this second installment. The addition we had in here was the sublime performance of Lee Van Cleef portraying Colonel Douglas Mortimer, who partnered up with the man with no name, with an equally strong performance delivered by Clint Eastwood. The two bounty hunters had to work together to take down Indio and his partners, one of the most fearful gangs in the west. Ennio Morricone returns with the famous whistle tune that spaguetti westerns became characterized for. The small watch playing a little tune was a great and intelligent subplot thrown by Leone to create extra tension during shootouts. 
Definitely the most underrated movie of the trilogy, and still lives in the shadow of the good, the bad, and the ugly.

The sequel to A Fistful Of Dollars, this is a fantastic follow-up. It has everything the first film has and the characters are more three dimensional and interesting. While, to be perfectly honest, I enjoyed the first film had slightly more, I wouldn't say this is the inferior film. The only flaw I can think of (and this is a personal opinion) is that the film boasts both brilliance and complexity, yet lacks some of the charm that is present in the other two of the series. As I say, this is a personal opinion, and most seem to think higher of this film, but there it is. Anyway, not to be negative, I still think it is a brilliant and fascinating movie, and all the praise it recieves is justified.
One of the best movie's I've ever seen. This movie has it all: great acting, memorable story, awesome actors, good humor. It's really really good.

Brilliant sequel with Clint Eastwood as the man with no name even though people call him Manco.
Also stars Lee Van Cleef as a bounty hunter who forms a partnership with Clint and goes after a killer who is worth a lot of money.
These Clint Eastwood spaghetti westerns have an unmistakable charm!
Cool western. Great music. Sweet ending. Two bounty killers teaming up... sweet.
a step up from the first

Another must-see Italian speghetti western.

A real improvment from a fistfull of dollars, just a year had gone by but everything was really much improved, the cinematography was great and a really good stand alone film...not just the "movie before the good one" some very innovative scenes and humor..and what sticks out there is the scene when they step on eachothers toes and shoot the hats....gotta have been awsome in 65, still is today aswell.

The thing I love about Leone's westerns is that they feel like so much more than a western. They have richer characterizations and plots than just archetypes and cliches.  This is a hell of a movie. It might be the best of the so-called "Man With No Name"  or "Dollars" Trilogy.  Lee Van Cleef is just as badass as Eastwood is.  Morricone's score is pretty awesome too, I love the motif of the little watch jingle.  I enjoyed every minute of this one, and while "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly" is a great classic epic western...this one is probably my favorite of the three.

With pulse-pounding suspense, a smouldering soundtrack and two staggering lead performances, Sergio Leone's second instalment in the 'man with no name' trilogy is tremendously entertaining and totally unforgettable. Eastwood and Van Cleef ooze coolness and the film's sleek cinematography renders almost every shot a work of art. At times the narrative is sluggish and the film's secondary characterisation is vague, yet Leone's direction is superb and the narrative is gripping from start to finish. A delicious classic of the Western genre and a real must-see movie.

On a technical level, The Good the Bad and the Ugly is a more well made spaghetti western. On an entertainment level, this film is superior, even more so than A Fistful of Dollars. An engaging and surprisingly connective western.
One of the best westerns
Classic! Great movie

For A Few Dollars More is the second part of what is commonly known as The Dollars Trilogy. What seperates good movies from great films is legacy, and how the film stands the test of time, and this film does it wonderfully. Unlike "A Fistfull Of Dollars" (1964), this story is completely origonal, and so simple, but so effective. We are also introduced to Lee Van Cleef, who, when paired up with Clint Eastwood's character "The Man With No Name", become one of the most badass killing teams that has ever graced the screen. The battle/dueling scenes are classic, and are quite epic to watch at times. An almost flawless film, but like the first part, I have to complain about the the audio, which at times is so off, actually takes away from the impact the scenes have to offer (for example, a man falls to the floor and dies, but the gunshot doesn't go off until two seconds later). That shouldn't be a surprise as the film cost almost nothing to make, and was edited in cheap Italian studios. For A Few Dollars More has enough gunshots and explosions to make anyone experience something fantastic.
better than original in many respects but just as awesome as original. the soundtrack is good and much of the music is repeated from original.

The most complete and spectacular of Leone's westerns, this really boils down to the once in a lifetime performances of Clint Eastwood and Lee Van Cleef. As world-class bounty hunters chasing the same contract, the two agree to an uneasy truce before turning every trick in the book to double-cross and one-up each other. It's an unrelenting barrage of stern-faced masculinity, bravado and marksmanship, with filthy hired hands perfectly willing to trade bullets around every other corner. As with each of the director's dust-soaked pictures, this film covers for its small budget with an excess of personality and buckets of atmosphere, which results in a tougher, bolder, more genuine take than the most expensive Hollywood blockbusters of today. The infamous showdown with a truly despicable set of bounties may be what sends this picture riding off into the sunset, but it's a quieter scene earlier in the story that's always stuck with me: two grizzled old hunters trying to impress one other with nothing more than an empty street, a set of pistols and a pair of bullet-riddled hats.
The last 10 minutes are perfect, the beginning of the end for the Western.
A satisfyingly original western with many a great and oddly cartoonish action scene.

The second in the "Dollars" trilogy has plenty of great laconic tough-guy action, a decent enough plot, and some dandy acting from Eastwood and Van Cleef especially, and the villain, "El Indio," is actually given a millimeter or two of depth. But a lot of it's silly, substituting stylization for sense, and there are some odd choices (e.g. a key device in the film is the gun fight when a musical watch stops playing, but in the scenes when this occurs, there is often intrusive music playing over what ought to be the key cue!). I'd call it a semi-classic.

What Sergio Leone gets right is the look of the period. Those sprawling empty spaces outside the townships, the saloons, the bounty posters etc. Apart from central characters, the extras he use for comedy does a job similar to what actors in similar roles do in Jackie Chan's dubbed movies. I don't understand why this movie is rated R as there is no swearing, excessive killing but hardly any graphic violence, a little nudity that could have been done without. The lead characters are extremely stylized, it is hard to connect with their situation as they seem to popping bad guys in the most ridiculous way possible. It features most things that are common in a western - railroads, bank heists, prison breaks, bounty hunting, revenge etc. It is an entertaining film with a conventional and neat story but could have done without a lot of sugar padding.
The second film in the Man With No Name trilogy. Great
super stylish and pure fun to watch.Eastwood and Van Cleeve are fantastic.Watch for Maria Volente's character' Indio'.might have inspired Gabbar Singh's character in Sholay.

One of the best westerns ever made. The music, the characters, the action all flow together perfectly. I loved the reveal at the end of the flick that illuminates upon a certain characters true motives. The villain of the picture was great sinister, and sadistic. Really a must see.
Another masterpiece, perhaps my favourite in the Dollars trilogy?

My favourite of the Dollars Trilogy. There's just a level of fun in For a Few Dollars More, that there isn't in the other films. The chemistry between Eastwood and Van Cleef is fantastic, and while maybe not as good as the scores for the two other films, Morricone's score is still excellent. I love the use of the watch chimes. Plus it has one of the best villain in film history!

Sergio Leone's For a Few Dollars More, is the second film in his acclaimed dollar trilogy. Once again we follow Clint Eastwood as the bounty hunter, the man with no name, in this film he goes under the name Manco. This time he's after the big score, to capture over a dozen bandits who have stolen money from a safe. But He is not alone, he have to work with another bounty hunter named Col. Douglas Mortimer (Lee Van Cleef) who's motive is revenge, not money. The most interesting new element in this picture is of course Lee Van Cleef's character, with might seems like a villain that every body is afraid of. But we get deeper into his character, and we start to care and sympathize with his goals. I also admire his fearlessness, specially in the scene where he light a match on The Hunchback's (Klaus Kinski) hump. An amazing scene with no dialogue, just a lot of tension between both characters. Thumbs up.

The middle element of Sergio Leone's "Dollars" trilogy, between "A Fistful of Dollars" and "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly." In my opinion, this is the best of the three, although there isn't much in it. A little more complex, ambiguous and interesting than "A Fistful of Dollars", and doesn't seem to lose its way like "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" does at times. But what the heck. All of them have great minimalist cinematography and superb Ennio Morricone scores and this trilogy changed cinema forever by bringing ambivalent moral codes and real characters into westerns. See them all.
The MUST see of all Eastwood westerns.
Favorite of the series

As slow as it is at times, Sergio Leone's For a Few Dollars More is a magnificent masterpiece that can speak a language so profound, words are not needed. In some of the most deep moments in this film, eyes do all the talking, and with the superb acting by Eastwood, Cleef and Volontia, it is easily captured. The action sequences are quick, brutal and methodical, encapsulating the character of the perpetrator. This film will always be known in history as one of the best. A parent to today's children.
Classic Man wth no name flicc....."This train will stop at Tulcomcarri".....lol

Better than A Fistful Of Dollars, but nowhere near as good as TGTBATU. It was not my intention, but since Netflix loves me so much, they sent me this one last, even though I had the correct order of the 3 films in my queue...whatever. So, as I was watching this one with my dad, we realized a few interesting things. Lee Van Cleef plays a different character, he's a good guy in this one! Gian Maria Volonte also plays someone else. And I kinda think Clint plays someone different in all 3 too, but I'm not sure yet. Ehh, whatevs. Another fantastic score from Morricone, and excellent camerawork from Leone. These are easily 3 of my favorite westerns (even though they're not really westerns...maybe we should call them spaghetti easterns!)

My favorite of the "Dollar" trilogy.  Leone's screen compositions and timing are exquisite, Eastwood seems to be having a mischievous blast, and Van Cleef adds an aura of mystery to the proceedings.  What puts it on top is its emotional edge, which isn't present in the other films.

Goes down in my list as the 2nd best western i have seen...Clint Eastwood Lee Van Cleef and Sergio Leone are deadly together......Gian Maria Volonte is superb as Indio.....great music....great plot...great buildup of the story.....

Clint Eastwood is brilliant...but i was surprised by Van CLEEF...his best definitely...and Gian Maria is pure evil....One of the greatest Westerns of all-time...one of the best movies of all time in fact.....Sergio Leone take a bow....

Sergio Leone is one of cinema's greatest directors. The second part in his Dollars trilogy, For A Few Dollars More is is an astounding sequel to For A Fistful Of Dollars. This follow up film is grand, and epic. This film is even bigger A Fistful Of Dollars. With every film that Sergio Leone made, he would outdo the next one. A tremendous, talented director, Sergio Leone is the only director in history to perfect the Western genre and deliver constantly entertaining Westerns. Clint Eastwood returns in top form as the man with no name. Accompanied by Lee Van Cleef who also star opposite Eastwood in the third part: The Good, The Bad and the Ugly, Sergio Leone's second film follows two bounty hunters (Eastwood, Van Cleef) who decide to team up to capture a criminal by the name of El Indio, brilliantly played by Gian Maria Vonlonte. As usual, Ennio Morricone's wonderful talents are used here and he delivers one powerful score. Morricone and Leone were an incredible team and their efforts are legendary. For A Few Dollars More has everything you'd expect from a Leone Western. A great story, mixed with drama and action. Leone was a master storyteller and I admire everyone of his films. I think that his films really revolutionized the way people make movies. For A Few Dollars More is an epic follow to A Fistful Of Dollars, and with that said, it's really hard to pick a favorite Sergio Leone Western. Each of his films are so well crafted and plotted that it's impossible to dismiss him. He was a powerful story teller, but I do not view him as a filmmaker, I view him as an artist. His pictures were art. Simple as that. This is yet another terrific piece of cinema that true film buffs will enjoy.

I started the trilogy the other way round... The movie purposefully gets slow at instances to leave the Sergio Leone effect... Clint and Van Cleef both are bloody cool... The end is nerve-wrecking... The typical Leone touch (read Super-natural touch) in music as well as story... Must watch :)

The second installment of the cult classic Spaghetti Western trilogy from Sergio Leone and Clint Eastwood is a unique experience. The director's approach to the Western movies stands in stark contrast from the so called Classic Westerns made in America. The adjectives to describe the director's style would be sweaty, dirty and unforgiving.

Much of the movie's strong resolve is thanks to the main star of the show. Back in the 60s the rather unknown TV show star Clint Eastwood really hit gold with Sergio Leone's Westerns. In the movies he pretty much defines his future career as a tough man with few words. The For a Few Dollars More as a movie can be considered as an evil and twisted triangle between the three main stars of the show. The main star being Clint Eastwood as the silent bounty hunter Monco who is looking to strike rich by catching and collecting reward from a rampaging group of desperados. Lee Van Cleef's character Col. Douglas Mortimer is after personal revenge and finds it beneficial to work together with Eastwood's enigmatic character. The collaboration of these two men take them to hunt down a common foe Indio, by Gian Maria VolontÃ (C), who is a ruthless outlaw out there to bring the world down burning. 

The story is easily approachable, straight to the point and fits well for the movie as it gives ample time for the actors to define their characters. Combining the unique style of the directors with the excellent performances by all of the main stars of the show, the For a Few Dollars More is an instant classic in my books and acts as a reference point to other westerns out there.
There are few musical themes that match the simple power of Ennio Morricone's watch melody in this film.
Lee van Cleef is such a badass. I did not realize the extent of his badassery until now. I blame "Sabata".
Like the prequel it was enjoyable and atmospheric. Again a little bit slow but can't argue with the acting and the haunting quiet of this film. Lots to chew on in this film.

thought this was even better than Fistful of Dollars

The Man with No Name trilogy keep getting better with the second entry "For a Few Dollars More" where along with Clint Eastwood and Gian Maria Volont returning, you've got the addition of Lee Van Cleef as a bounty hunter. This is Sergio Leone's thrid best film in his career and Ennio Morricone's second best score to date alone with gorgeous cinematography.

There goes the neighborhood. And the idea that guns are best in single barrels. Take pride in continuity of the fact that Sergio Leone settles for nothing less than the very best, to dig his teeth in the girth of a genre he knows and loves, and that he stores his biggest ideas for. The times start getting nailed down in "For a Few Dollars More", the stellar sequel to '64's heavily-influenced "A Fistful of Coins". The offspring of early-20th century tech geeks are tossing up new design innovation for weapons, and folks are finally wizening to the often limitless financial potential in a lifeless body when you aim sharp enough to drown their tell-tale hearts, like hippie freaks reading their munchies for foreign paranoia.

In a new branch of the Western woods, Clint Eastwood's Man With No Name comes to run smack into a bounty hunter named Col. Douglas Mortimer (Lee Van Cleef) shaking up residents in hot pursuit of bandit El Indio (Gian Maria Volonte). One beef: the Man's tracking the same scent. A team-up? Why not -- Mortimer keeps a mind for the impending, while No Name the storied traditional. So the latter (referred to in this film as Manco, meaning in Spanish "one-armed") breaks from jail an Indio crony and ever so dangerously slips into the gang as they prep a bank heist in El Paso, once mission impossible for the crew. It's all blueprint for a crackdown on Indo and his $10K government DOA; ditto for the godfather's gang, among whom include a young Klaus Kinski as a Mortimer left-standing jonesing to spill the beans on their charade.

But besides all that, what's the harm of dabbling in some foul play? Oh yeah, there's also the conscience rumor that Mortimer or No Name might use their undisclosed knowledge to over the shoulder finish each other off. It gives "For a Few Dollars More" a sense of dread that makes "A Fistful of Dollars" look innocent in comparison. Because in Leone's massive West, retribution sways in the endless shrapnel autopsy for blood like we're in Chinatown and there's no water. Mortimer and No Name masquerade on the same side in the creation of the tri-state's new vocational border, eyes peeled not for the obscurity of a gunshot but in the humane schizophrenia nearest the trigger. As usual, if shit were to blow, it wouldn't end at the tip of a single finger -- you're prey to a whole fistful.

The man with no name is back for more action in "For a Few Dollars More." Clint brings back the rapacious rifleman out to cash in with the life of the bounty hunter. The criminal Indio has escaped from jail and hatches a new plan to rob the El Paso bank. So the man learns there is another dog in the fight; Mortimor, an ex colonel now in the bounty business. Spaghetti western angles, dialogue and action permeate this opulent sequel. Clint is cocky with a side of insouciance. Fun, violent, sexy. The epitome of what makes a good western.
A perfect example of a sequel out shining the original. One of the best Western films ever made.

This is actually my personal favorite film of the trilogy. Everything about it is so iconic. The film is overlooked because it is the middle film, but I feel like it deserves more recognition. The ending gun fight alone is worth watching the entire film for. The cast is fantastic from Clint Eastwood to Gian Maria VolontÃ (C), and even a young Klaus Kinski pops in to say hello. The standout however is Lee Van Cleef's Colonel Mortimer. His characterization of The Man in Black is brilliant. The final revelation at the end, which involves his character and ties up a major plot point, gives me chills each time I see it.

After wathcing Fistful of Dollars, I was eager to watch the second movie in this great Man With No Name trilogy, and after watching it I must say -  it was so awesome. The movie is thrilling, intensive, built properly and simpley - enjoyable! Sometimes it was hard for me to believe this movie is from 1965. Clint Easwood and the other actors are just wonderful, and the directing is splendid too. Now all I have to do is to find 3 available hours and watch the last movie of this terrific trilogy (and probably the best of them) - The Good, The Bad and The Ugly. For the time being, For a Few Dollars More gets 4.5\5.

With a more likable Man With No Name and the strong performances from Lee Van Cleef and Gian Maria VolontÃ (C), the second installment of Sergio Leone's legendary Dollars Trilogy is superior to the first. Much of what applied to A Fistful of Dollars goes here as well, with VolontÃ (C) in a new villain role and Clint Eastwood's Man With No Name (now called "Manco") as mysterious as ever. This time, however, he has met a true equal in skill, in the form of Cleef's Colonel Mortimer. However, instead of gunning each other down, they decide to team up to capture the highly wanted bandit El Indio, with his mysterious watch tune. The plot flows much better than the first Dollars film, as it is original and not just ripped from a Kurosawa film, and Manco is more likable than Joe in the sense that him and Mortimer are clearly "the good guys." Overall, a better film than the first, and a remarkable Spaghetti Western.

One of the better Spaghetti Westerns with all the best player: directed by Spaghetti Western Master Sergio Leone, music by the brilliant Ennio Morricone, Clint Eastwood and Lee Van Cleef as tough cool Bounty Hunters, Gian Maria VolontÃ (C) and Kalus Kinski as Crazy Bandits (and Kinski can pretty much out-crazy anyone just by opening his eyes).

This pretty much cements the Dollars Trilogy as one of my favorite film series. It does what a good sequel should, it gives you a longer, darker, more detailed story. A more twisted villain, and a new hero that adds a interesting dynamic to the story. Lee Van Cleefs character was, to me, the most interesting part of the movie. Sergio Leone has a way of making the first 75% of these movies good, yet somewhat bland, but his endings always blow me away despite the fact that everyone knows the bad guy is gonna get his at the end. The man knows how to set up a shoot out.
Like all of Ennio Morricone's work, the score is incredible. Sergio Leone crafted an exciting story here, and its just great fun all around.

This is a great western.  Sequels rarely surpass the original, but it does this time.  Adding Van Cleef's character scared me because who wants Eastwood to share time on screen?  It really works though, with some great moments in the final firefight.

A bit more fleshed out and complete than Fistful although Leone rarely ever let logic in a script interfere with his filmmaking.  Lee Van Cleef is great as Colonel Mortimer and gives No Name some good competition in the bounty hunting field. He's more in it for revenge concerning the villain El Indio, nicely played for violent craziness by Gian Maria Volont. (There seems to be a progression in the crazy villain types in the No Name series which reaches its pinnacle of infamy with Eli Wallach's Tuco, but El Indio is sufficient.) Anyways, there's also Klaus Kinski in a bit part and some awesome gunplay. It could have been shorter, but again Leone compromised with no one concerning length and always took plenty of time to develop his characters and story.

Whilst 'A Fistful of Dollars' introduced Sergio Leone's new, grittier Wild West, 'For A Few Dollars More' continues to ground the genre whilst pushing even further. 

I firmly believe this is a sequel to 'Fistful of Dollars'. Eastwood s the man with no name is back and he looks, sounds, and acts identical to how he did in the previous instalment. However, an extra outlaw is added into the mix in the form of another Western Legend: Lee Van Cleef. Famous for his role in 'High Noon', Van Cleef has all the features of a classic villain. Indeed, when we first see him ruthlessly killing for bounty, we get a sense that he is the main antagonist. What surprises us then, is when he lends a helping hand, and ultimately is the hero who slays the real antagonist - whilst Eastwood smokes and acts almost as a referee. 

In this regard: Van Cleef is as prominent as Eastwood - and is just as memorable. Whilst in 'A Fistfull of Dollars', it was Eastwood s performance that stood out the most, in 'For A Few Dollars More', it is Van Cleef who steals the show. He is intimidating to the last, yet for this movie somehow manages to be incredibly likeable. 

As is standard for a sequel, the entire scope is raised. The whole 'adventure' seems to take place over a much larger area. The settings are much more expansive, and the cast is much more extended to include a sub-villain in addition to Van Cleef as a sub-hero alongside Eastwood. The plot is much more layered, with seemingly two plots merged together - the two bounty hunters (Van Cleef and Eastwood) rivalling for the prize before coming to a mutual respect (in what is my personal favourite scene of the movie), and then the two working together to destroy a group of bandits who simply want to rob a bank. With any normal movie, the Director would either just focus on one, or demote the other to a sub-plot. This may mean that having what seems like two movies placed one-after-the-other makes the whole movie rather over-long. And that is the only flaw: that there is just too much. 

Simultaneous to Leone breaking the boundaries and innovating not just the western, but filmmaking altogether; Ennio Morricone likewise does this with his musical score. It is a bridge - with the main theme incredibly similar to 'A Fistful of Dollars', yet we hear some samples (particularly during the duelling sequences) of what is yet to come in arguably the greatest movie soundtracks of all time: 'The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly'. 

Overall: this outing is far superior to the first, but in retrospective the movie is merely building up to Leone's next, and arguably greatest, movie...

The immediate predeccessor to "The Good, The Bad, and the Ugly," "For a Few Dollars More" is overlong, but very entertaining. The movie follows two bounty hunters (Clint Eastwood and Lee Van Clief) in a quest to find some vicious criminals in order to collect a great some of money (for the time that is). There are some pretty grim scenes up to the climax, especially considering when this film was released, particularly when the chief thug (Gia Maria Volonte) murders a family, including an infant, in order to gain revenge on someone who had originally caught him. That was a little disturbing. Other than that, it is visually stunning and quite suspenseful western film. I wish it was little shorter, but perhaps that's just my own little problem. This was the warm up to the great, iconic film that followed under Sergio Leonne's direction. A very good warm up indeed.

The Man with No Name joins forces with a rival bounty hunter to capture the crazed outlaw Indio.

The second installment in The Dollars Trilogy is is regarded by most critics as the weakest of the series.  However, while i feel it's not as important as the original (A Fistful of Dollars created the spaghetti western after all) and not as memorable as the final picture (The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly has overwhelming style),  For a Few Dollars More is nevertheless, every bit as good as it's brethren with it's borderline cartoonish confrontations between characters and tense atmosphere.  The action is over-the-top, carefree, and fun while the screen looks great filled with such a vast, beautiful, and harsh landscape.

For a Few Dollars More is undoubtedly a Sergio Leone film.  He is a patient director, utilizing long silences where the actors communicate with facial and body gestures rather than vocals and the violence is high in frequency and glorified in nature.

The picture has the unfortunate qualities of being the sequel to a groundbreaking endeavor (A Fistful of Dollars) and exhibiting restraint of intrusive style compared to it's successor (The Good, The Bad, The Ugly), but For a Few Dollars More is still an incredible work of stylized western themes and male bravado.
Even Better than the first Leone's second installment is a brilliant Western worth Checking out.

I find myself becoming more of a sucker for spaghetti westerns with each subsequent film. Sergio Leone's second part in his "Dollars Trilogy" follows two bounty "killers" as they attempt to infiltrate a gang of outlaws who, in turn, are trying to pull off a big bank robbery. I went into the movie blind so I didn't know what to expect. Naturally I had a blast. Clint Eastwood and Lee Van Cleef just ooze confidence and sheer awesomeness. I found myself waiting in earnest for each scene that they had together. Along with having these two western powerhouses, other Sergio Leone regular Gian Maria Volonte makes yet another appearance. His character is much better in this film than in A Fistful of Dollars in my opinion. The gunplay is as impressive as ever and, at times, kinda played for laughs. One scene in particular involving just Eastwood and Van Cleef had me chuckling to myself quite a bit. Also, in keeping with the fantastic soundtrack of the first film, Ennio Morricone makes another awe-inspiring soundtrack. The films with his soundtracks are always better for them and this one is no different. It adds the perfect amount of tension, bravado, and even comedy at times. I would have to say that this is pretty close to taking the top spot of the trilogy for me.

A sequel to "A Fistful of Dollars" seems like a foregone conclusion considering its worldwide success. But in 1964, there was nothing inevitable about it. Sergio Leone had received no financial compensation from the considerable box office of his first Western and wished to make a personal, partially autobiographical project about growing up in Trastevere during the 1930s. However, he was under pressure to repeat his Western success and Italian lawyer Alberto Grimaldi offered Leone 50% of the profits plus expenses. This was an offer that a man with a wife and children to support couldn't refuse. So he set out on the development of  the ironically titled "For a Few Dollars More," wishing to top his earlier film. This determination shows in the finished product. "For a Few Dollars More" is a more ambitious film than its predecessor in terms of narrative, character and style and it's the film which really shows Leone developing the epic side of his filmmaking which would come to fruition in "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly." It may not be Leone's best film, but it may be his most purely enjoyable; an exercise in narrative filmmaking which brims with style and confidence.

Leone brings back the Man With No Name - this time briefly given the name Manco - in the shape of Clint Eastwood and explicitly makes him a bounty hunter (called bounty killers in the film) with no other motivation than money. This gives the film a specific historical context during the late 19th Century when law and order in the West was maintained in a decidedly fragile state by a haphazard system of local Sheriffs and traveling Judges. Bounty hunters were encouraged as an efficient way of finding and dealing with fugitives. Eastwood's all ready iconic character is joined by a new figure; Colonel Douglas Mortimer played the great character actor Lee Van Cleef. Mortimer is also a bounty hunter but one haunted both by his past as a soldier and a tragic family history. After a brief, witty confrontation , the two men team up with the common goal of bringing to justice El Indio (Volonte), a deranged, dope-addled bandit who is inextricably linked to Mortimer's family tragedy.

The sweeping confidence of the film reflects a director who is finally able to do what he wants in the way he wants. Leone's work is immensely stylish, packed with increasingly exotic use of close-ups and pacing which, while never slow, is a little stately in a manner which often recalls Luchino Visconti. There is more intentional humor in this film than in its predecessor with whole sequences built up for the sake of a humourous pay-off, such as the scene with the apples towards the end. There's a lushness to the film, both in its stunning visuals which make full use of the landscape in a way which Leone would intensify in his next two films, and in its emotional richness, largely supplied by the character of Colonel Mortimer. In "Fistful," there's not a great deal of motivation or even characterisation. In this film, Mortimer's character is all motivation and, partly due to Lee Van Cleef's sympathetic and witty portrayal, he comes across as the main target for our sympathy. Virtually every Spaghetti Western which followed the huge success of this movie in Italy would feature a flashback to explain the motivations of a particular character but few are either as simple or as effective as the one here. Leone keeps this in the background at first, with unexplained memory 'flashes' from El Indio that are later revealed as his connection with Mortimer. The pocket watch watch, with the initially unexplained portrait of a lady, is well used too, providing another angle of narrative suspense.


Everything in"For a Few Dollars More" seems a little bigger than in its predecessor. The violence is a little more graphic and sadistic, Carlo Simi's production design of El Paso - Leone's first great bustling period location - is on a larger scale and the psychopathic, sociopathic behaviour of El Indio is more melodramatic and theatrical. Gian Maria Volonte takes the opportunity to go over the top with both hands, consuming the scenery with relish as one of the nastiest, most irredeemable bad guys in cinema history. In contrast to this slightly garish conception, Clint Eastwood's performance seems all the more restrained and funny. He gets comic effects simply by doing very little and allowing all around him to emote their way into the stratosphere. His character is made even less heroic, again being the hero mostly because of his charisma and finally being slightly redeemed through his friendship with Mortimer. This friendship adds a more human dimension to the whole film, bringing in complex emotions which the first movie ignore. Leone originally wanted Lee Marvin for the role but couldn't afford the actor's asking price and Van Cleef's warm, likable performance is masterful; a mature, if cynical, reflection contrasted with Eastwood's youthful arrogance, even though Van Cleef was a mere five years older.


Leone's style is developing and the movie contains most of the elements which will be considered hallmarks of his film making. Along with the harshly cynical view of the world - good men have to turn to violence because of the greed and corruption around them - and extreme sclose-up shots, we get more religious iconography creeping in - the church in which El Indio delivers his speech about robbing the bank being an example - and the recurring motifs such as the circular dance of death during the final gunfight.All in all "Dollars is a worthy second film in an unintended trilogy with the best saved for last.

Not quite as good as A Fistful Of Dollars but still a very good watch, For A few Dollars More sees Clint Eastwood return as the man with no name. Making his debut in the Dollars trilogy is Lee Van Cleef, playing a sharp shooting Colonel who goes bounty hunting while away from the army. As too does Eastwood's character, until the two join forces to bring down a volatile bandit named El Indio whose just escaped from prison. Just like its predecessor this film is awesome and cool, and goes deeper into the characterization and backstories of the characters. The only thing that lets it down ever so slightly is probably the partnership of Van Cleef's and Eastwood's characters as they are two different sides of the same coin; both wanting the same thing but for a different reason. But as I say only ever so slightly. Sergio Leone has done it again with another gripping and stylish western which strengthens the Dollars trilogy. Eastwood, Van Cleef, and Gian Maria Volente all deliver good performances and make a quality ending when everything is explained and comes to a head.

The premise alone makes this a fascinating and entertaining movie from start to finish. Whats so different about it from all of Leone's other movies is that it focuses less on the setting and more on the characters of the movie, rather than how their story fits within a particular historical setting. With "Once Upon a Time in the West"," the Good, The Bad, and The Ugly" and even "Once Upon a Time in America", we see the environment shaping the characters, and in this we see the exact opposite. And the revenge story fits in so perfectly at the end, giving even more meaning to the masterfully crafted story.
